front.title: In Situ OAM Profile for the Linux Kernel Implementation

abstract.t: In Situ Operations, Administration and Maintenance (IOAM) is used for monitoring network performance and for detecting traffic bottlenecks and anomalies. This document defines an IOAM profile that is used in the Linux kernel implementation.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: IOAM is used for monitoring traffic in the network by incorporating IOAM data fields into in-flight data packets.

An IOAM profile defines a use case or a set of use cases for IOAM, and an associated set of rules that restrict the scope and features of the IOAM specification, thereby limiting it to a subset of the full functionality.

This document introduces a profile of IOAM that is used in the Linux kernel implementation. The profile is intended to formally specify the subset of features that are in scope, and to enable other implementations to interoperate with the Linux implementation.

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: The Linux kernel implementation enables the functionality of any of the following nodes:

One possible use case is a set of Linux-based hosts that function as IOAM encapsulating and decapsulating nodes, interconnected by IOAM transit nodes that are not necessarily Linux-based. Thus, Linux-based implementations are expected to interoperate with other implemenations that comply to this profile.
Another possible use case is a homogenous setting in which all IOAM nodes are Linux-based.

section.title: IOAM Version
section.t: The current profile is based on [draft-ietf-ippm-ioam-data-14], which is a work-in-progress version of IOAM.

section.title: IOAM Options
section.t: The current profile uses the Pre-allocated Trace Option. It is assumed that one IOAM option is used in an IOAM encapsulated packet.

section.title: Encapsulation
section.t: The IOAM encapsulation uses an IPv6 tunnel, as defined in .

As illustrated in , the IPv6 tunnel is used with an IPv6 Extension Header. This extension header is used for the IOAM Pre-allocated Trace Option, as defined in draft-ietf-ippm-ioam-ipv6-options-06, which is a work-in-progress version of the IPv6 IOAM option.

The IPv6 Extension Header is a Hop-by-Hop option, that contains the IOAM trace option. As illustrated in , the first 2 octets are the Hop-by-Hop option header , followed by a 2 octet Padding field. The following 4 octets are the IOAM IPv6 option header [draft-ietf-ippm-ioam-ipv6-options-06]. The IOAM Option includes the 8 octet Pre-allocated Trace Option header [draft-ietf-ippm-ioam-data-14], followed by the Option Data.

section.title: IOAM Supported Data Fields
section.t: The current profile supports all the data field types that are defined in [draft-ietf-ippm-ioam-data-14].

Note that the Linux implementation does not update the Checksum Complement field and the Transit Delay field when functioning as an IOAM transit node. However, this does not prevent interoperability with other IOAM nodes that support these fields.

section.title: IOAM Option Pre-allocated Trace Header Flags
section.t: This profile does not use any of the IOAM flags other than the Overflow flag.

section.t: TBD.

section.title: Timestamp Format
section.t: This profile uses the POSIX timestamp format.

section.title: Profile Coexistence
section.t: It is assumed that the current profile is used in a confined administrative domain in which no other IOAM profiles are used. Therefore, it is assumed that the current profile does not coexist with other profiles.

section.title: Validity
section.t: An IOAM transit/decapsulating node that receives a packet with IOAM options that do not comply to the current profile is expected to forward/decapsulate the packet without IOAM processing, if it is able to do so. If a decapsulating node is not able to decapsulate an IOAM option that is not compliant to the current profile, the packet is discarded.
